title: Existent

articles.content:
The building-block of man’s knowledge is the concept of an “existent”—of
something that exists, be it a thing, an attribute or an action. Since it is a
concept, man cannot grasp it explicitly until he has reached the conceptual
stage. But it is implicit in every percept (to perceive a thing is to perceive
that it exists) and man grasps it implicitly on the perceptual level—i.e., he
grasps the constituents of the concept “existent,” the data which are later to
be integrated by that concept. It is this implicit knowledge that permits his
consciousness to develop further.
articles.attribution:
“Cognition and Measurement,”
Introduction to Objectivist Epistemology, 5–6

acknowledgement:
“Cognition and Measurement,”
